Switch clarity ON OFF Privacy policy close Study Research Explore Connect School of Computing Science Our staffDr Kitty MeeksMr Ethan KellyZhen Tian Professor Kitty Meeks Professor of Theoretical Computing Science (School of Computing Science) telephone: 0141 330 8469 email: Kitty.Meeks@glasgow.ac.uk Room 406, 1 Lilybank Gardens, School of Computing Science, Sir Alwyn Williams Building, University of Glasgow Import to contacts https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5299-3073 Biography I joined the University of Glasgow in 2014, as a Lecturer in the School of Mathematics and Statistics; I moved to the School of Computing Science in 2016, where I held a Royal Society of Edinburgh Personal Research Fellowship from 2016 to 2021.  My work is currently funded by an EPSRC Fellowship (2021-2030). I gained my MMath in Mathematics and Computer Science (2009) and DPhil in Mathematics (2013) from the University of Oxford, and from 2012 to 2014 I worked as a Postdoctoral Research Assistant at Queen Mary University of London. Research interests My research involves developing new techniques for the design of provably correct and efficient algorithms, and applying these techniques in as many domains as possible - from Social Network Analysis to Precision Medicine. I am particularly interested in parameterised algorithms, counting complexity, and temporal networks. From 2016 to 2021, I held a Personal Research Fellowship from the Royal Society of Edinburgh, to work on the project Exploiting Realistic Graph Structure. The goal of this work was to help bridge the gap between theory and practice in the design of network algorithms by developing our understanding of how structural properties of real datasets can help us to extract information from them more efficiently. Since October 2021, I my research has been funded by an EPSRC Fellowship, Beyond One Solution in Combinatorial Optimisation.  In this project I aim to develop new techniques for the design of algorithms that do more than just find a single "best" solution: we aim to find all good solutions or, failing that, to estimate the number of good solutions and sample randomly from this collection.  This will involve combining techniques for the design of parameterised algorithms and approximate counting algorithms.  While these abstract techniques will be very widely applicable, we have identified several target applications in the field of Precision Medicine which will be explored during the project. I also work extensively on algorithms for temporal graphs, which model networks whose connections change over time (e.g. transport networks, social networks), with a focus on understanding the structural properties of these networks that can be leveraged to design practical algorithms.Research groupsFormal Analysis, Theory & Algorithms Publications List by: Type | Date Jump to: 2025 | 2024 | 2023 | 2022 | 2021 | 2020 | 2019 | 2018 | 2017 | 2016 | 2015 | 2014 | 2013 | 2012Number of items: 50.2025 Agdur, Vilhelm, Enright, Jessica ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0266-3292, Larios-Jones, Laura ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3322-0176, Meeks, Kitty ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5299-3073, Skerman, Fiona and Yates, Ella (2025) Approximating temporal modularity on graphs of small underlying treewidth.
